name: Cloud Deployment Models and Business Benefits
description: Flashcards covering cloud, on-premises, and hybrid deployment models and the strategic business benefits of cloud adoption.

cards.front: A startup wants to avoid investing in physical servers and instead build and host their new app entirely using cloud-native services. What deployment model does this represent?
cards.back: This represents a **cloud-based deployment** model, where all components of the application run in the cloud, offering scalability and reduced infrastructure management.
cards.example: The startup uses AWS Lambda, Amazon RDS, and Amazon S3 to build a serverless backend entirely in the cloud.
cards.subject: Deployment Models for Cloud Computing

glossary.definition: A model where all components of an application run in the cloud, either newly built or migrated.

cards.front: A healthcare company must keep patient records in-house due to regulations, but also wants to analyze those records using cloud-based machine learning. What deployment model fits best?
cards.back: This is a **hybrid deployment**, which connects cloud-based services with on-premises infrastructure to meet business and compliance requirements.
cards.example: Patient data is stored in an on-premises database, while AWS SageMaker is used in the cloud for model training.
cards.subject: Deployment Models for Cloud Computing

glossary.definition: A deployment model where cloud resources are integrated with on-premises infrastructure.

cards.front: An enterprise uses virtualization tools to manage applications within its own data center. What cloud deployment model does this describe?
cards.back: This is an **on-premises deployment**, also known as private cloud, where infrastructure is hosted and managed internally.
cards.example: The company uses VMware and Hyper-V in their data center to run business-critical apps without using public cloud resources.
cards.subject: Deployment Models for Cloud Computing

glossary.definition: A model where resources are deployed and managed in an organization’s own data center using virtualization and management tools.

cards.front: Why do businesses prefer cloud computing when they want to avoid overprovisioning and underutilized resources?
cards.back: Cloud computing allows businesses to **stop guessing capacity**, scaling resources in or out on demand and only paying for what they use.
cards.example: A retailer uses Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling to handle spikes in traffic during Black Friday without paying for unused capacity the rest of the year.
cards.subject: Deployment Models for Cloud Computing

glossary.definition: A cloud benefit where you dynamically scale resources instead of estimating infrastructure needs in advance.

cards.front: A company is looking to reduce time spent managing data centers and focus on building new customer features. Which cloud benefit applies?
cards.back: The benefit is **stopping spending money on running and maintaining data centers**, allowing more focus on application development and innovation.
cards.example: By migrating to AWS, the company decommissions its physical servers and assigns the IT team to new cloud projects.
cards.subject: Deployment Models for Cloud Computing

glossary.definition: A cloud benefit that eliminates the need to manage physical infrastructure, shifting focus to value creation.

cards.front: How does cloud computing enable global reach for an online education platform within minutes?
cards.back: By leveraging AWS’s global infrastructure, businesses can **go global in minutes**, deploying applications close to users for low latency and high performance.
cards.example: An ed-tech company launches their application in AWS Regions across Asia and Europe within hours to serve international students.
cards.mnemonic: Global in Minutes = AWS Regions Ready
cards.subject: Deployment Models for Cloud Computing

glossary.definition: A benefit of cloud computing where applications can be deployed worldwide using AWS’s global infrastructure.
